60a488f3b36c052d65592e563a5d24a7 (07:32): Anyone familiar enough with prototype to tell me why I can't embed a Hash object inside of one of my own objects? http://pastebin.com/766024
0ff551825eefd6e6b2c3185f7e00b54f (07:32): The paste 766024 has been moved to http://erxz.com/pb/1433
9a2b9664480d18b4f9bdb1fa5bd20b0a (07:32): you can get the plugins that are installed aswell.
9a2b9664480d18b4f9bdb1fa5bd20b0a (07:32): GoSox,  for (i in navigator){ alert(i+': '+navigator[i]); }
9a2b9664480d18b4f9bdb1fa5bd20b0a (07:34): prototype.js has a hash object?
9a2b9664480d18b4f9bdb1fa5bd20b0a (07:35): wonder why.  any regular object can be a hash.
6735c9ab9b1ac69d7d2f449177128eca (07:36): maybe they add methods
6735c9ab9b1ac69d7d2f449177128eca (07:36): and IE doesn't support adding prototype methods on builtins
60a488f3b36c052d65592e563a5d24a7 (07:37): kicken: Because there aren't nice methods for dealing with hash objects on built-in objects
caa6d297c180089f6078e94288312156 (07:42): if 'var a = Array;' then will 'a.name = "MyName"; ' be an object, or in the array?
60a488f3b36c052d65592e563a5d24a7 (07:44): kismet_: What will cause a to have a property named "name"?
60a488f3b36c052d65592e563a5d24a7 (07:46): kismet_: name will be a member on the array object a, but not in the array.  For that you need a[index] = "MyName";
caa6d297c180089f6078e94288312156 (07:47): that's perfect, then. exactly what i hoped/expected

caa6d297c180089f6078e94288312156 (08:32): erm, so i'm subclassing the Array object, but I want the new class List to accept the same arguments as when you'd declare a new Array
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:33): when you say class do you mean prototype?

caa6d297c180089f6078e94288312156 (08:33): so I want ' new List(10); ' to do the same as ' new Array(10); ', and i'm using the Prototype library for Class.create(), which gives me an initialize function

caa6d297c180089f6078e94288312156 (08:35): problem: if List IS an Array (i've used Object.extend(List.prototype, Array.prototype) for inheritance), then the 'this' keyword should refer to the List/Array?

43097fd1091d2f6113274fa95ef3d37d (08:35): i've got a strange anomaly in IE.  a link that appears at the end of a some text and is wrapping correctly to the next line.  however, IE thinks that the link is positioned on the previous line.  this is verified by my code and by IE's new developer tools (i'm outlining the link tags).  any ideas or knowledge on what's going on?
caa6d297c180089f6078e94288312156 (08:36): but the statement 'this = new Array(arg1);' is throwing errors
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:39): you can't assign to 'this': it's not a variable
a0e4ec720a249a3e5162548adbcc8f4f (08:40): ahemm
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:40): it's an operator: http://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Core_JavaScript_1.5_Reference:Operators:Special_Operators:this_Operator
a0e4ec720a249a3e5162548adbcc8f4f (08:41): dreamwave:  too ambigous to call it
a0e4ec720a249a3e5162548adbcc8f4f (08:41): 2000 possible reasons
caa6d297c180089f6078e94288312156 (08:42): wait, i think i figured it out
caa6d297c180089f6078e94288312156 (08:44): here's a short line: ' var ArrayList = new Array;  ArrayList.prototype = {
caa6d297c180089f6078e94288312156 (08:46): collectItems: function() { for (var i in this) { blah blah blah } }

caa6d297c180089f6078e94288312156 (08:47): now that for..in loop, that will include more than just the contents of the Array, right? it's gonna spit out methods and properties of the ArrayList object, too, right?
9a2b9664480d18b4f9bdb1fa5bd20b0a (08:48): probably
9a2b9664480d18b4f9bdb1fa5bd20b0a (08:48): Adding elements to the Object prototype makes it stop working on regular arrays too.
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:48): kismet_: yes
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:49): did someone mention changing Object's prototype?
a0e4ec720a249a3e5162548adbcc8f4f (08:50): I like cheese
caa6d297c180089f6078e94288312156 (08:50): i'm trying to keep the functionality of the Array in this new class/object, I don't want to have to write a ton of wrapper code to a contained Array object
caa6d297c180089f6078e94288312156 (08:51): ArrayList IS an Array, not ArrayList HAS an Array
9a2b9664480d18b4f9bdb1fa5bd20b0a (08:51): deltab, before me, no.  just an fyi.
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:52): I suggest not giving it an initial capital letter
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:52): yes, since it's not a constructor
caa6d297c180089f6078e94288312156 (08:53): I'm flumoxxed how to make that happen, though
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:53): make a function
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:53): call it ArrayList
9a2b9664480d18b4f9bdb1fa5bd20b0a (08:54): I'm kind of doubting you can extend the Array and still be able to use it like an array (ie, in a for/in or with []).  Maybe it's possible though.
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:54): not with for/in
caa6d297c180089f6078e94288312156 (08:54): it's lookin really iffy
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:54): but you can still use a counter variable and length
3c26b6648764f1ab4360aa71da5d760b (08:55): You can extend it .. but for/in returns the new prototypes as an element
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:55): kicken: and set its prototype property to a new Array
caa6d297c180089f6078e94288312156 (08:56): i could lose the for/in, i just need a way to access only the Array contents, and skip any object properties i give the subclass
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:56): use a counter variable and length
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:56): for (var i = 0; i < al.length; i++) { ... }
caa6d297c180089f6078e94288312156 (08:56): you mean a regular for loop
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:58): function ArrayList() { }

caa6d297c180089f6078e94288312156 (08:58): i wish i had a book for this stuff. The Mpls central library has O'Reillys "Javascript: The Definitive Guide" from 1998, and I think the newest is still from back in 2001
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:58): ArrayList.prototype = new Array();
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:58): var al =new ArrayList();
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:58): al.push('foo');
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:58): al.push('bar');
2bed0f7df931083c71cbe381c5a9427d (08:58): for (var i = 0; i < al.length; i++) { print(al[i]); }
